clinical_study.brief_title: Bone Regenerative Techniques in Endodontic Microsurgery
clinical_study.official_title: Healing After Endodontic Microsurgery Using Resorbable Collagen Based Bone Augmentation Material: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to evaluate periapical healing after endodontic microsurgery with the use of guided tissue regeneration. The study population includes patients diagnosed with persistent periapical pathology and scheduled for surgery at UPenn endodontic clinic. Patients undergoing routine endodontic surgery will be randomly assigned to receive resorbable collagen in the osteotomy site to promote bone formation. Healing will be assessed radiographically at 6, 12, and 18 months.

detailed_description.textblock: Root end surgery is conducted to eliminate infection and inflammatory lesions in the tissues below the roots of teeth previously endodontically treated. Healing is assessed through the resolution of signs and symptoms as well as bone regeneration in the area below the root. In cases where the bone defect is significant, it is recommended to use a membrane to allow the bone to heal without invasion of cells from the gum tissues into the lesion. In small lesions, the efficacy of using augmentation material is not determined. Routine root end surgery with small lesions is often conducted with or without augmentation material. The purpose of this research is to compare periradicular healing after root end surgery in endondontic lesions with and without the use of resorbable collagen material.

primary_outcome.description: The outcome of the surgery will be assessed by qualitatively evaluating bone regeneration through radiographs using well-established criteria. Rud's criteria categorize healing using periapical films into four categories: complete healing, incomplete healing, uncertain and unsatisfactory healing. Cases with complete or incomplete healing are considered to be successful. Modified Penn criteria classify healing using cone-beam CT into complete, limited, and unsatisfactory healing. Success is assigned to cases with complete and limited healing.

arm_group.description: Subjects assigned to this group will receive Foundation in the bone defect before suturing the surgical site.

intervention.description: Collagen-based, bone filling augmentation material used to stimulate bone formation in extraction sockets or bone defects in the alveolar ridge.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adult.
- Intact coronal restoration with no sign of leakage.
- Class B (small lesion) and C (large lesion) periapical lesions. (Kim and Kratchman 2006)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with medical conditions and contraindications to surgery.
- Minors.
- Pregnancy.
- Teeth with signs of coronal leakage.
- Teeth with vertical root fractures.
